docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut's attorney general filed a federal lawsuit today against four of the state's largest H.M.O.'s charging them with improperly denying medical claims, obstructing access to prescription drugs, delaying payments to doctors and misinforming patients about their rights to appeal decisions about their health care. The civil lawsuit, filed in United States District Court in Hartford, seeks to represent thousands of clients who, according to Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, have suffered physically and financially from the organizations' practice of putting profits ahead of patient care.

headline.main: Connecticut Sues H.M.O.'s Over Handling Of Patients

docs.abstract: Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal files federal lawsuit against four of state's largest HMO's, charging them with improperly denying medical claims, obstructing access to prescription drugs, delaying payments to doctors and misinforming patients about their rights to appeal decisions about their health care; four HMO's are Oxford Health Plans, Cigna Health Plans and its CIGNA HealthCare of Connecticut subsidiary, Foundation Health Systems and its subsidiary, Physicians Health Services of Connecticut, and Anthem Health Plans and its Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut; all four HMO's issue statements stressing their commitment to high-quality patient care (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: History and recent experience suggest that Gov. George W. Bush's plan to turn much of the administration of Medicare over to private insurance companies and health maintenance organizations (front page, Sept. 6) is a lose-lose proposition.

headline.main: Bush and Medicare: A Flawed Plan

docs.abstract: Diane Archer letter warns that George W Buch's plan to turn over Medicare administration to private sector is lose-lose proposition (S)
